title: Elementary Science
subject: science-elementary
description: Explore fundamental science concepts across biology, physics, and chemistry

items.text: A rock is [blank] because it doesn't grow or need food.
items.explain: Non-living things don't grow, eat, breathe, or reproduce. A rock is non-living.

items.text: A tree is [blank] because it grows and makes seeds.
items.explain: Living things grow, reproduce, and respond to their environment. Trees are living.

items.text: Which is non-living? A [blank]
items.explain: A car doesn't grow or reproduce. Cars are non-living objects made by people.

items.text: In a food chain, [blank] make their own food using sunlight.
items.explain: Plants are producers. They use sunlight to make food through photosynthesis.

items.text: Animals that eat only plants are called [blank].
items.explain: Herbivores eat only plants. Examples: deer, rabbits, cows.

items.text: Animals that eat other animals are called [blank].
items.explain: Carnivores eat meat. Examples: lions, wolves, hawks.

items.text: The [blank] of a plant absorbs water and nutrients from soil.
items.explain: Roots anchor the plant and absorb water and minerals from the ground.

items.text: The [blank] of a plant make food using sunlight.
items.explain: Leaves contain chlorophyll and perform photosynthesis to make food.

items.text: The [blank] carries water from roots to leaves.
items.explain: The stem transports water and nutrients throughout the plant.

items.text: A fish lives in a [blank] habitat.
items.explain: Fish are adapted to live in water (ocean, rivers, lakes).

items.text: A camel is adapted to live in a [blank] habitat.
items.explain: Camels store water and survive in hot, dry desert environments.

items.text: A polar bear lives in a [blank] habitat.
items.explain: Polar bears have thick fur and are adapted to cold arctic environments.

items.text: Water is [blank] when it's ice.
items.explain: A solid has a fixed shape. Ice is water in solid form.

items.text: Water in a cup is a [blank].
items.explain: A liquid takes the shape of its container but has a fixed volume.

items.text: Steam is water in [blank] form.
items.explain: A gas has no fixed shape or volume. Steam is water vapor (gas).

items.text: Cutting paper is a [blank] change.
items.explain: A physical change changes appearance but not what something is made of.

items.text: Melting ice is a [blank] change.
items.explain: Melting changes the state but ice is still water molecules. It's physical.

items.text: Burning wood is a [blank] change.
items.explain: A chemical change creates new substances. Burning wood makes ash and smoke.

items.text: A [blank] is a simple machine that helps you lift heavy objects.
items.explain: A lever uses a fulcrum to multiply force, making lifting easier.

items.text: A [blank] reduces friction and helps things roll.
items.explain: Wheels and axles reduce friction, making it easier to move objects.

items.text: A [blank] is a simple machine used to split or cut things.
items.explain: A wedge converts force to push things apart. Examples: axe, knife.

items.text: Light is a form of [blank] energy.
items.explain: Radiant energy includes light and heat from the sun or other sources.

items.text: A moving ball has [blank] energy.
items.explain: Kinetic energy is the energy of motion. Moving objects have kinetic energy.

items.text: A stretched rubber band has [blank] energy.
items.explain: Potential energy is stored energy. A stretched band can do work when released.

items.text: In the water cycle, [blank] is when water changes to vapor.
items.explain: Evaporation is when liquid water heats up and becomes water vapor (gas).

items.text: In the water cycle, [blank] is when water vapor cools to liquid.
items.explain: Condensation forms clouds when water vapor cools and becomes liquid drops.

items.text: [blank] is when water falls from clouds as rain, snow, or hail.
items.explain: Precipitation is any form of water falling from the sky to the ground.

items.text: [blank] is the day-to-day conditions of the atmosphere.
items.explain: Weather changes daily (sunny, rainy, cloudy, etc.).

items.text: [blank] is the average weather over many years.
items.explain: Climate describes long-term patterns (e.g., Florida has a warm, humid climate).

items.text: A desert has a [blank] climate.
items.explain: Deserts have very little rain and high temperatures most of the year.
